channel.title: Xbox live radio
channel.description:
OK, quick rundown of what I've done so far: Took headset apart, checked pinouts, soldered wires to board, tested results. Steps I neglected to do: Research the Xbox Live audio streaming platform.
Well, I, "successfully" came up with an xbox live radio streaming system, though it doesn't work. Right now I don't have pictures, but I'll take some and post them in a bit. Basically what I've done is I've soldered a 3.5mm jack to the ports M-, and M+ on the board in the Xbox Live headset. I then plugged the headset into my audio out port on my PC, and tried playing some music. It does infact play sound from the computer, and my party can hear it. The issue is, the quality is nonexistent. It's just a lot of white noise really, you can discern sounds if you know the song or the video, but it's still just a bunch of gibberish.
My attempts to fix the issue were to no avail. I tried using Mono instead of stereo, nope. Tried changing level of volume, nope. Different types of media, such as voice, music, sounds. Nope, nothing worked. So really the only thing I can take away from this experiment, is that the Xbox Live audio platform just doesn't support my venture.
If anyone else has an thoughts on this, or maybe a fix, it'd be appreciated.

item.title: Xbox live radio
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

That wouldn’t make it sound like white noise though, you’d still be able to hear it fine, itd just be all mids

EDIT: In case anyone was interested, a song most would recognise through a very conservative bandpass, the xbox live one probably wouldn’t be anywhere near this tight:

http://www.zshare.net/audio/6427309769dded0a/

(no need to download to listen, can use wmp in browser)

Read full topic

item.title: Xbox live radio
item.dc:creator: @newbiehacker newbiehacker
item.description:
@newbiehacker wrote:

xbox live headsets probably have a bandpass filter to only allow the frequencies of the human voice, music would have too much dynamic and too large a frequency range to be transmitted well across xbox live

Read full topic

item.title: Xbox live radio
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

It’s very possible it could be bad soldering, though I was using a very large soldering iron, and the board is very small. I just don’t think that was the issue. I mean, when I used a pair of headphones, and held them next to the mic, the quality was the same.

Read full topic

item.title: Xbox live radio
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

Is the audio compressed? It might be too much for your internet to handle.

Read full topic

item.title: Xbox live radio
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

runescape3dude:

try a 3mm jack

I accidentally hit two, I meant 3.5mm.

Read full topic
